+James H JV did handle it. In personal communication to CK, JV asked him to 
remove the reference from his book and issue an apology. CK refused to do 
that.

In the meantime (remember, we're talking about less than one month's time), 
as a result of CK telling the world that JV said, "A few SEALs deserved to 
die.", his book went from being one more mediocre Iraq War story to the top 
of the NYT's Best Seller List.

Again, keep the perspective: CK didn't tell this story in McP's over a pint 
of ale, he went on the O'Reilly Factor and other nationally broadcast 
programs and repeated this disgusting lie several times. And you're saying 
JV should have just sucked it up and left it alone?

You said, " Then after Cheif left us, JV pursued the suit knowing full well 
Taya could have used that money."

At the time CK was murdered, the lawsuit was already a year along. Legal 
motions and counter-motions had been made. Witnesses had been deposed 
(including six hours of CK's taped deposition). JV had already invested 
thousands of dollars of his own money, while CK had invested, well, 
nothing, other than the lies he told about JV. All of CK's legal fees were 
being paid by Harper-Collins, the publisher.

And your statement, "...Taya could have used that money." is almost 
laughable if it wasn't so pathetic. When CK was murdered in Feb, 2013, 
"American Sniper" had already been on the NYT's Best Seller List, a Best 
Seller for Amazon and Barnes + Noble. Warner Bros. bought the rights for 
the movie in May of 2012. It has become "...the highest-grossing film of 
2014 in the United States... the highest-grossing war film of all 
time...and Eastwood's highest-grossing film to date."

Taya Kyle is not now, was not at the time of the Jury verdict, and has not,

on his own. Man to man. Then after Cheif left us, JV pursued the suit 
knowing full well Taya could have used that money. She's is single mom. 
That's fucked up.

+James H There are two distinctively different issues regarding Chief Kyle 
that VERY few people bother to separate.

One: He was "the most successful sniper in US Military history." That's an 
accomplishment he earned and deserves the recognition he's received.

Two: On nationally broadcast radio and television shows he made serious 
statements about Jesse Ventura. Statements which JV, when he heard about 
them, took great exception to, claiming they weren't true.

Stop right there before you jump to the conclusions you so dearly cling to, 
whatever they are. BOTH of these men are rightfully called SEALs. Different 
generations, different wars, but they both served, they both went through 
the training, they were both prepared to do their duty. And that's why this 
becomes/became such a big deal.

JV has been a part of the SEAL Community for years. Terry “Mother” Moy, the 
owner of McP's Irish Pub, where the alledged incident occurred, was a SEAL 
and an Instructor of JV. Both of them, JV and Moy, and Greg McPartlin (the 
founder of McP's) for that matter, were doing their Active Duty Service 
before CK was even born. JV had been a frequent attendee at SEAL Graduation 
ceremonies to honor the new SEALs. But you didn't know that, I bet. I know 
I didn't, and there's no reason why we should.

So this conflict is between two SEALs. And if that's where it remained, it 
would be of little note or consequence to any of us. But it didn't stay 
there. CK went on national radio and TV shows and made accusations against 
a fellow SEAL that were very significant and serious. CK told the world 
that JV said, "A few of those guys deserved to die."

Get that image in your head: Someone saying that a former SEAL, a man who 
has encouraged and supported SEAL graduates for years, a man who has been a 
member of that community for years, said that, "A few of those SEALS 
deserved to die. Some of those SEALs that I have been supporting for longer 
than you, Chris Kyle, have been alive, you're telling the world that I said 
some of them DESERVED TO DIE?"

I'm a Viet Nam Vet. I, fortunately, came home alive. 58,000+ of my fellow 
Servicemen didn't. I have my own opinion about that war, and it's not a 
positive one. But you will NEVER hear me say that any one of those 58,000+ 
who didn't make it back alive DESERVED to die there. And if I heard someone 
declaring that they heard me say that I'd haul their ass into court, too. 
No matter who it was!

I fully understand why JV took CK to Court. CK told a lie about JV. Not 
just a little white lie, but a sick, disgusting, stomach-turning lie that 
struck at a very core value that JV held near and dear: that our VETs in 
general, and SEALs in particular, deserve respect and honor, not a specious 
comment about "some of them deserve to die".

So kudos to Chris Kyle for being the "most successful sniper in US Military 
history".

But shame on him for telling lies about a fellow SEAL. 160 confirmed kills 
doesn't excuse even one instance of willful betrayal.

PS
For the record, please get your facts straight. Jesse Ventura rightly sued 
Chris Kyle for defamation of character. When CK met with his untimely 
death, that suit was already a year old, and it was amended to "Jesse 
Ventura v The ESTATE of Chris Kyle", not Taya Kyle. Taya Kyle's name was 
included because she was the Executor of his Estate, she was not being sued

A jury awarded former Minnesota Governor Jesse Ventura $1.8 million for a 
defamation suit he filed against Navy SEAL Chris Kyle. The SEAL, who was 
killed on a shooting range in February 2013, claimed in a bestselling book 
that he had punched Ventura in a bar fight after the governor made 
derogatory remarks about the elite military unit. RT’s Ameera David speaks 
with Ventura to get his thoughts on the win, as well as the backlash from 
pushing forward with the lawsuit after Kyle’s death.﻿
